item.title: The state as a relationship
item.description:
‚ÄúThe state does not exist above us, but between us.‚Äù

When we speak about the state, most of us imagine something distant and impersonal.
Laws, offices, regulations ‚Äî systems that seem to hover above our lives,
something we merely react to or try to comply with.

Yet the state was not originally a structure of power.

It was the living fabric of a community.
The way people organised life together
so that no one was left alone,
and children could grow up in safety.

item.title: Trust as an economic force
item.description:
‚ÄúTrust is the only currency
that cannot be taken ‚Äî only given.‚Äù

Most economic systems are built on scarcity.
Scarcity of time, resources, money, attention ‚Äî
and competition follows naturally from this.

If someone wins,
someone else must lose.

This logic is deeply embedded in how we operate.
Yet there is something that is not scarce.

Trust.

It cannot be owned.
It cannot be regulated.
It cannot be forced.

And yet it is the foundation of every human and economic relationship.

item.title: Value as responsibility
item.description:
‚ÄúWhat we consider valuable shapes who we become.‚Äù

In today‚Äôs world, the word value is almost automatically
associated with money or profit.

As if that were the only measure:
how much it brings in,
what it costs,
what it‚Äôs worth.

Yet real value is not what we possess ‚Äî
but what we create with responsibility.

The question is not how much we have accumulated,
but what we have added to the world.

item.title: Work as joy
item.description:
‚ÄúWork is not hard because it is work ‚Äî
but because it has been disconnected from joy.‚Äù

For most people, work is something
to get through.

Tasks.
Deadlines.
Obligations.
Expectations.

As if work were a necessary evil ‚Äî
something to endure
so that life can begin afterwards.

But work did not originate this way.

Not as coercion.
Not as survival mode.
But as creation.

Once upon a time, work meant
taking part in shaping the world.
Contributing.
Seeing the meaning in what one does.

item.title: Attention as the new currency
item.description:
Flow is born where attention becomes presence.

For a long time, the world‚Äôs economies were built on
money, resources, and time.

But in the 21st century, something has shifted.

The most valuable thing is no longer what you have ‚Äî
but what you give your attention to.

Attention has become the new currency.
The scarcest resource of all ‚Äî
and yet the only one each person truly owns.

Companies, media, and political systems all compete
to capture it, steer it, or fragment it.

item.title: Value without ownership
item.description:
‚ÄúWhat you cling to dissolves.
What you share expands.‚Äù

The world many of us grew up in taught us
that what we own is what defines us.

Ownership became the foundation of
security, status, and identity.

And yet, as awareness slowly widens,
another truth begins to surface:

the most meaningful forms of value
are not the ones we hold onto,
but the ones we allow to flow.

Love.
Attention.
Knowledge.

item.title: Connection as a resource
item.description:
‚ÄúConnection is not a luxury ‚Äî it is infrastructure.‚Äù

For a long time, the modern world believed that progress was driven by
money, technology, or productivity.

But if we look more closely,
everything rests on one thing:

connection.

Connection between people.
Connection between a person and their work.
Connection between a person and the world.

Every form of value,
every piece of knowledge,
every real innovation
is born from connection.

item.title: Cooperation as our natural state
item.description:
‚ÄúA flower does not compete.
It simply opens.‚Äù

The world we grew up in taught us
that life is competition.

That if someone wins,
someone else must lose.

That humans are selfish by nature,
and only external rules keep us in check.

But this is not true.

A child does not want to be better than others ‚Äî
they want to connect.

To play.
To share.
To wonder.

Nature does not compete either.

item.title: Responsibility as freedom
item.description:
‚ÄúResponsibility turns from a burden into freedom
when it is not born of pressure,
but when space opens through it.‚Äù

In most systems, responsibility feels heavy.

Something you have to take on.
Something strict.
Something that weighs on you.
Something you are held accountable for.

This kind of responsibility is usually born from fear.
Fear of making mistakes.
Fear of consequences.
Fear rooted in a lack of trust.

But when trust is present,
when there is space,
when a system has a human tone,

item.title: The system that begins within us
item.description:
‚ÄúThe future does not arrive from the outside.
The future is you.‚Äù

Most people believe
that the problems of the world must be solved from the top down.

Through laws.
Through institutions.
Through large, system-level decisions.

As if our lives were shaped by distant forces,
and we were merely carried along by them.

Yet every real change
always begins within.

In a faint realisation.
In a subtle inner tension: ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt quite right.‚Äù
In an unexpected insight that stops us for a moment.
In a new way of tuning into the world.

item.title: We‚Äôre in this shit together
item.description:
We‚Äôre in this shit together.
And that‚Äôs why it might actually work. üòè

Most of our systems are built on a quiet assumption: that we should have things under control.

That we should be coping. That we should be fine. That struggle is a personal failure.

So we perform. We optimise. We hide the cracks.

And the moment something really goes wrong, people don‚Äôt ask for help ‚Äî they disappear. They burn out. They break down. Sometimes they literally die alone rather than say: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do this by myself.‚Äù

item.title: Our definition of success is misaligned
item.description:
An elderly man was taken to the emergency department.

Over the course of the night, the entire right side of his body froze.
So severely that doctors said
his hand may need to be amputated.

This didn‚Äôt happen because help wasn‚Äôt available.
It happened because he didn‚Äôt ask for it.

Today, people would rather suffer ‚Äî
even die ‚Äî
than ask for help.

And this isn‚Äôt an individual tragedy.
It‚Äôs a systemic outcome.

item.title: Not every change happens overnight
item.description:
More and more, I see that the Human Growth Model is not pushing against capitalism.

It‚Äôs a natural consequence of it.

Mental health entered the conversation back in the 1970s. At first on an individual level ‚Äî mostly through symptoms: burnout, stress, breakdowns.

Later, it appeared on a social level: charities, grassroots initiatives, support projects. Important steps ‚Äî but largely symptom-focused.

Then something else began to emerge: awareness.

First in individuals. Then in communities. And eventually in organizations.

item.title: Why do companies optimise for individuals rather than collective?
item.description:
Most companies are powered by the collective. Yet they optimise individuals in isolation.

Performance is rarely created by one person. It emerges from interaction, timing, trust, and shared context.

Yet most organisations focus on:

  • boxed roles
  • individual KPIs
  • responsibility matrices
  • optimisation in silos

Instead of optimising connection.

When the system doesn‚Äôt support natural collaboration, something predictable happens: People get stuck. They feel exposed. They start scheduling meetings ‚Äî not out of curiosity, but out of fear.

item.title: Would a mentally healthier world actually move slower?
item.description:
Not because people would be lazy. But because there‚Äôd be nothing to run from.

Most of today‚Äôs speed isn‚Äôt driven by ambition. It‚Äôs driven by internal pressure: ‚Äì proving ‚Äì performing ‚Äì not falling behind

When mental wellbeing becomes the baseline, that mode simply stops activating.

If it‚Äôs good where you are, you don‚Äôt need to escape elsewhere.

Travel stops being avoidance and becomes curiosity. Work stops being pressure and becomes creation. Performance stops being the goal and turns into a side effect.

item.title: Today, I had a key to everyone.
item.description:
Somehow, everything connected.

I walked into a disagreement with a friend. He brought up the ‚Äúwitch-hunting‚Äù parallel. I didn‚Äôt react immediately. I just said that, to me, it looked like a classic pattern of enemy-making: ‚ÄúI‚Äôll protect you from the enemy‚Äù ‚Äî only back then, with far more brutal tools. Same mechanism as today. We paused. A shared silence.

Then he explained the logic behind his view. I listened. He had to rush, so we didn‚Äôt close it ‚Äî I just said: we‚Äôll come back to this. And that felt right.

item.title: The HGM collision map
item.description:
It doesn‚Äôt happen overnight.
It starts with small frictions.

With thoughts that feel familiar:

  • ‚ÄúWhy am I tired when, on paper, everything is fine?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhy is it hard to ask for help, even when there is someone to ask?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhen did work turn into survival?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhy do I constantly feel like I have to prove myself?‚Äù

These are not personal failures.
They are collisions.

A collision between an old system of functioning
and the human nervous system.

item.title: We all need room to breathe.
item.description:
Lately, I‚Äôve realised something.

I‚Äôm not waiting for people to ‚Äúwake up.‚Äù
I‚Äôm waiting for their normal self
to finally have room to breathe.

I don‚Äôt believe people are inherently lazy, broken, or uninterested.
I think they‚Äôre overwhelmed.
Pulled apart.
Disconnected from themselves.

And when someone is finally given a bit of space ‚Äî
not pressure,
not motivation,
not expectations ‚Äî
but presence‚Ä¶

something very different happens.

The human shows up.
Not aggressive.
Not defensive.
But curious. Connected. Alive.

item.title: I‚Äôll handle it on my own
item.description:
There‚Äôs a sentence that keeps coming back to me.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll handle it on my own.‚Äù

For a long time, I thought this was strength. Independence. Maturity.

Lately, I see it more as a learned pattern.

As if somewhere early on we absorbed the idea that asking for help is awkward, leaning on others is uncomfortable, and a ‚Äúproper‚Äù adult doesn‚Äôt bother people with their needs.

But there‚Äôs a quiet twist in this story.

item.title: Why don‚Äôt we design work for flow?
item.description:
Today I found myself wondering why driving can‚Äôt be an experience.

Not racing.
Not speeding.
But presence.

Why do we design roads as if humans were a flaw in the system?
As if joy were dangerous.
As if attention could only be maintained through restriction.

And yet, when a person enters flow ‚Äî even while driving ‚Äî
they don‚Äôt fall apart.
They come together.

They don‚Äôt become aggressive.
They become present.

item.title: Most motivational content no longer inspires me
item.description:
‚Ä¶it even irritates me sometimes.

And I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs a bad sign.

Motivation often exists where something is missing:
energy,
meaning,
safety,
direction.

It tries to push people forward
in systems that quietly drain them.

But when people are mentally well,
when they feel safe, connected and valued,
they don‚Äôt need to be constantly motivated.

They move naturally.
They create.
They take responsibility.
They contribute ‚Äî
not because they‚Äôre pushed,
but because it feels aligned.

item.title: When no one needs to prove anything
item.description:
A pattern I‚Äôve been noticing more and more clearly.

There are situations that just work.

A conversation.
A shared doing.
A small project.

And when that happens,
what stays with us isn‚Äôt what we did.

It‚Äôs that suddenly, time disappeared.

‚ÄúWait‚Ä¶ is it already this late?‚Äù

This doesn‚Äôt happen when everyone is trying very hard.
It happens when no one needs to prove anything.

That‚Äôs when roles soften.
Status fades into the background.
Sometimes even the way we address each other shifts ‚Äî
not by decision,
not by gesture,
but simply because we grow closer.

item.title: HGM explained - in the language of the old system
item.description:
From the perspective of the old system, HGM is not a revolution.
It‚Äôs a logical optimisation we simply haven‚Äôt dared to think through until now.

For a long time, the underlying assumption has been roughly this:

People perform best under pressure.
Safety makes people complacent.
Fear keeps the system moving.

So we build control.
We measure, monitor, reward, and punish.
And we accept that ‚Äúthis is just how it works.‚Äù

item.title: Why don‚Äôt radically stripped-down companies truly take off?
item.description:
For a long time, something didn‚Äôt make sense to me.

We constantly hear about organisations
that don‚Äôt treat their people well.
No real involvement.
No trust.
No genuine human attention.

And yet ‚Äî they don‚Äôt collapse.

That bothered me.

Over time, the picture started to clear.

These companies do function.
But mostly in survival mode.

They deliver.
But they don‚Äôt unfold.
They remain stable.
But they‚Äôre not alive.

The potential is there ‚Äî
it just never gets released.

item.title: Scarcity & fear ‚Äî and what lies beneath
item.description:
There is a state many of us live in.

Not loud.
Not dramatic.

More like a constant, background tension.

The feeling that it‚Äôs not enough.

Not enough money.
Not enough security.
Not enough time, energy, or reserves.

And from this sense of scarcity, we learn how to function.

We learn that
everything must be handled alone,
asking for help is weakness,
if you slow down, you fall behind,
if you don‚Äôt perform, there will be consequences.

item.title: Connection as care
item.description:
Lately, I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about how isolated we tend to become when we‚Äôre ill.

Almost automatically, many of us fall into the belief:
‚ÄúThis is my problem. I need to deal with it on my own.‚Äù

But if we take a small step back, something else becomes visible.

In reality, we are all part of communities ‚Äî
families, neighbourhoods, cities, countries, and ultimately a shared world.
And every community is strongest when its members are well.

item.title: Why aren‚Äôt companies teaching with humour and play?
item.description:
The more I work on the Human Growth Model (HGM),
the clearer one thing becomes:

Humour and play are not ‚Äúextras‚Äù ‚Äî
they are the deepest, fastest, most human ways of learning.

And yet, most organisations still hold on to an old belief:

Work must be serious.
Learning must be serious.
Humour is risky.
Play is unprofessional.

But here‚Äôs the paradox.

Play creates focus.
Humour increases learning retention by 400‚Äì500%.
Laughter reduces stress and opens the mind.

item.title: The awakening
item.description:
‚ÄúChange doesn‚Äôt begin with the system, but with how we look at it.‚Äù

There is a moment when something quietly shifts.

When you realise that what you have been calling ‚Äúthe world‚Äù is not something distant.

Not a separate system. Not ‚Äúthe economy‚Äù. Not ‚Äúpolitics‚Äù.

But something you are part of.

Every decision, every moment of attention, every turning away or turning towards is gently woven into the living fabric we call the human world.

item.title: About
item.description:
Hi, I‚Äôm Pete.

The Human Growth Model (HGM) isn‚Äôt self-help and it isn‚Äôt an ideology. It‚Äôs a repeatable, human-centred way of thinking about one core question: how we become mentally well ‚Äî and then build from that state.

This space is a collection of notes, experiments, and emerging frameworks. I often start from small, everyday moments (because that‚Äôs where reality leaks through), then translate them into a systems view.

The goal isn‚Äôt optimisation or endurance. It‚Äôs to create from inner stability.
